title: Five stunning images of Nebula captured by NASA Hubble Telescope - India.com
summary:
Five stunning images of Nebula captured by NASA Hubble Telescope

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India.com

The article showcases five breathtaking images of different nebulae captured by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, along with brief descriptions of each nebula's characteristics and significance.

  • Abell 78: A unique planetary nebula formed from a star that exhausted its nuclear fuel, collapsing into a white dwarf.
  • Snowman Nebula: An emission nebula located 6,000 light-years away in the constellation Puppis.
  • Nebula With Superbubble: Known as N44, it contains glowing hydrogen gas and massive stars.
  • Prawn Nebula: A massive stellar nursery located in Scorpius, approximately 6,000 light-years from Earth.
  • Necklace Nebula: A planetary nebula formed from the remains of a Sun-like star, glowing brightly in its Hubble image.
"The glowing remains of an ordinary, Sun-like star create the stunning appearance of the Necklace Nebula."

This article illustrates the beauty and diversity of nebulae discovered by the Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting their importance in the study of the universe.

title: Marius, the man who named Jupiter’s Galilean moons - The Hindu
summary:
Marius, the man who named Jupiter’s Galilean moons

Published on: December 15, 2024

Simon Marius, a 17th-century astronomer, is known for naming the four largest moons of Jupiter despite being overshadowed by Galileo, who claimed to have discovered them first. The debate over Marius' contributions continues today.

  • Marius was an astronomer, mathematician, physician, and calendar maker born in 1573 in Gunzenhausen, Germany.
  • He independently observed Jupiter's moons on December 29, 1609, claiming to see “four tiny stars” aligned with the planet.
  • In 1614, Marius published Mundus Iovialis, detailing his findings including Jupiter’s moons and the Andromeda Galaxy.
  • His suggested names for the moons—Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto—were influenced by the work of Johannes Kepler.
  • Galileo accused Marius of plagiarism in 1623, resulting in ongoing debate about Marius' contributions to astronomy.
“While it is nigh impossible for us to determine if Marius does deserve credit for independently discovering the four major satellites of Jupiter, there’s no doubt that he was the one who gave them the names that are now in use.”

The legacy of Simon Marius highlights the complexities of scientific discovery and the importance of acknowledgment in the history of astronomy. Despite controversies, his contributions to the naming of Jupiter’s moons remain significant.

title: Webb Telescope unveils a Milky Way-like galaxy from the early universe - Madhyamam
NASA’s Webb Telescope Reveals Firefly Sparkle, a Milky Way-Like Galaxy - Gadgets 360
summary:
NASA’s Webb Telescope Reveals Firefly Sparkle, a Milky Way-Like Galaxy

Publication Date: December 11, 2023
Source: Gadgets 360

A galaxy nicknamed the Firefly Sparkle has been detected by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, marking a significant discovery regarding the early universe and its galaxies.

  • The Firefly Sparkle galaxy existed approximately 600 million years after the Big Bang.
  • It has a mass similar to the Milky Way at a comparable stage of development.
  • Distinctive for having ten active star clusters undergoing staggered star formation.
  • Gravitational lensing greatly enhanced visibility, allowing detailed observation of its components.
  • Two companion galaxies are expected to influence Firefly Sparkle's evolution over billions of years.
"Each clump is undergoing a distinct phase of evolution." - Chris Willott

This research, part of Webb's CAnadian NIRISS Unbiased Cluster Survey (CANUCS) programme, provides unparalleled insights into the universe's formative years.

title: 120 meteors per hour! Did you know about Geminid meteor shower? - ET Now
summary:
120 meteors per hour! Did you know about Geminid meteor shower?

Publication Date: December 14, 2024

Source: etnownews.com

The Geminid meteor shower is set to showcase a dazzling display of meteors, with peak visibility expected on December 14, 2024. This celestial event is famed for producing up to 120 meteors per hour.

  • The Geminid meteor shower occurs annually, known for its bright and fast meteors.
  • Visible on December 14, this year’s event will allow viewers to see approximately 120 meteors per hour.
  • The meteors travel at impressive speeds of 79,000 mph (127,000 kph) or 22 miles per second.
  • The meteor shower runs from November 19 to December 24, peaking in mid-December.
  • Finding a dark spot away from city lights will enhance viewing conditions.
“Under ideal conditions, up to 120 Geminid meteors can be seen every hour at its peak, with meteors notable for their brightness, speed, and golden color.”

Be sure to find a comfortable viewing location and enjoy the spectacular Geminid meteor shower as it lights up the night sky!

title: Jupiter’s Moon Io Shows No Magma Ocean as New Findings Explain Volcanic Eruptions - Gadgets 360
summary:
Io's Volcano Mystery Solved: No Global Magma Ocean Found

Publication Date: December 12, 2024 | Source: Nature

Recent research has revealed that Jupiter's moon Io does not have a global magma ocean beneath its surface, challenging previous theories about its volcanic activity and implications for other celestial bodies.

  • The study analyzed data from NASA's Juno spacecraft and historical data from the Galileo mission.
  • Findings indicate that Io's interior is solid, contrary to previous beliefs of a molten layer.
  • Over 400 active volcanoes exist on Io, with lava sourced from localized pockets of melt in the mantle.
  • The research has wider implications for understanding tidal heating on exoplanets orbiting M-dwarf stars.
"The absence of a global magma ocean on Io challenges the assumption that such exoplanets would host extensive molten layers."

This significant discovery not only reshapes our understanding of Io but also prompts a reevaluation of geological models for other celestial bodies influenced by tidal forces.

title: 8,000-Kilometer Deep Oceans on Uranus and Neptune? A Scientist’s Revelation - Indian Defence Review
summary:
8,000-Kilometer Deep Oceans on Uranus and Neptune? A Scientist’s Revelation

Published on: December 14, 2024 | Source: Indian Defence Review

A groundbreaking study suggests that Uranus and Neptune may conceal vast oceans beneath their atmospheres, potentially up to 5,000 miles deep, which could revolutionize our understanding of these ice giants.

  • Research led by Burkhard Militzer from UC Berkeley utilized advanced computer simulations.
  • Layered structure proposed: thick hydrogen-helium atmosphere, deep ocean of water, and compressed hydrocarbons.
  • The presence of these oceans may explain the unique magnetic fields of these planets as observed by NASA's Voyager 2.

Implications for the search for extraterrestrial life

The discovery raises potential for habitable environments on icy moons, such as Miranda, which might harbor subsurface oceans.

Advancements in planetary modeling

Militzer's team developed a model simulating 540 atoms under extreme conditions, aligning with Voyager 2's measurements, enhancing the credibility of the new theory.

"One day, I looked at the model, and the water had separated from the carbon and nitrogen. What I couldn’t do 10 years ago was now happening." - Burkhard Militzer

Future exploration and confirmation

NASA proposes a flagship mission to confirm the existence of these oceanic layers by 2034, taking advantage of a rare planetary alignment for faster travel.

These findings reshape our understanding of ice giants and expand the possibilities for extraterrestrial life.

Astronauts’ stunning views of Earth from space - Hindustan Times
summary:
Astronauts’ stunning views of Earth from space

Publication Date: December 4, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

This article highlights breathtaking images captured by astronauts from space, showcasing the beauty and diversity of Earth.

  • Earth is the only known planet in our solar system with life.
  • Astronauts witness Earth’s full beauty from space.
  • The curvature and color contrasts of the planet are apparent from orbit.
  • Natural phenomena like hurricanes are visible yet appear peaceful from space.
  • The ISS orbits Earth every 90 minutes, allowing astronauts to see multiple views of the planet daily.
Astronauts’ views of Earth from space offer a stunning reminder of the planet's beauty.

The stunning imagery captured by astronauts serves as a reminder of the fragile beauty of our planet and the need for its preservation.

title: NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter May Become Weather Station for 20 Years on Mars - Gadgets 360
summary:
NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter May Become Weather Station for 20 Years on Mars

Publication Date: January 18, 2024

Source: Gadgets 360

The Ingenuity Mars Helicopter, originally deployed by NASA for flight testing, will now function as a weather station after sustaining damage during its 72nd flight. Despite losing its flying capabilities, the helicopter's systems remain operational for data collection.

  • The helicopter suffered rotor damage during its last flight on January 18, 2024.
  • Ingenuity will record telemetry and take images every sol as a weather station.
  • The navigation system struggles with uniform Martian terrain, complicating safe landings.
  • Communication relies on the Perseverance rover, located 3 kilometers away.
  • Ingenuity can potentially operate for up to 20 years, collecting valuable data.
"She's now going to continue on as a weather station of sorts, recording telemetry and taking images every sol." - Teddy Tzanetos, Ingenuity's project manager

As Ingenuity's mission transitions, JPL is now considering the development of a new six-rotor Mars helicopter designed for extended scientific exploration.

title: 6 Very Beautiful Space Images Captured By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Very Beautiful Space Images Captured By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Dec 14, 2024 | Source: Times Now

This article showcases six stunning images captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, celebrating the beauty and mystery of the cosmos while highlighting the telescope's remarkable capabilities.

  • Orion Nebula: A captivating view showing the formation of over 3,000 stars.
  • Tarantula Nebula: Close-up of a stellar nursery with extreme phenomena in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
  • NGC 2174 (Monkey Head Nebula): A vibrant image celebrating Hubble's 24th year in orbit.
  • Inky Abyss (NGC 2022): A vast expanse of gas from a dying star.
  • Westerlund 2: A remarkable image of a star cluster released for Hubble's 25th anniversary.
  • Mystic Mountain: A dramatic portrayal of gas and dust, shaped by intense radiation.
"The pillar is gradually being eroded by intense radiation from nearby luminous stars, creating a scene even more striking than fiction."

The images serve as a reminder of Hubble's significant contributions to our understanding of the universe, showcasing its lasting impact on astronomy and science.

title: Ligand-engineered copper nanoclusters may aid in fight against CO2 emissions - Tech Explorist
summary:
Ligand-engineered copper nanoclusters may aid in fight against CO2 emissions

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Tech Explorist

This article discusses a groundbreaking initiative by researchers to enhance the efficiency of electrochemical CO2 reduction using ligand-engineered copper nanoclusters, demonstrating copper's potential in sustainable chemistry.

  • Research conducted by Tohoku University, Tokyo University of Science, and University of Adelaide.
  • Engineering of copper nanocluster surfaces at the atomic level to improve selectivity and sustainability in carbon reduction.
  • Focus on electrochemical CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR) which convert excess CO2 into valuable products.
  • Two Cu₁₄ nanoclusters were created with different thiolate ligands, showcasing the potential for varying product selectivity.
  • The study highlights the importance of intercluster interactions in determining nanocluster stability and catalytic performance.
“To achieve this breakthrough, our team had to modify NCs at the atomic scale. However, it’s very challenging since the geometry of the NCs was heavily dependent on the precise parts that we needed to alter.” — Professor Yuichi Negishi
“These findings are pivotal for advancing the design of Cu NCs that combine stability with high selectivity, paving the way for more efficient and reliable electrochemical CO2 reduction technologies.” — Professor Yuichi Negishi

This research underscores the critical role of collaboration and innovative technology in addressing global carbon emission challenges.

title: NASA's critical warning: A 200-foot, airplane-sized asteroid is approaching Earth at high speed tomorrow - Moneycontrol
SpaceX Launches 22 Starlink Satellites Into Orbit on Falcon 9 Rocket From California - LatestLY
Scientists find alien-like predator in the deep ocean, name it Darkness - Hindustan Times
summary:
Scientists find alien-like predator in the deep ocean, name it Darkness

Date: Dec 14, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

A recent study reveals the discovery of Dulcibella camanchaca, a new predatory amphipod found at a depth of 7,902 meters in the Atacama Trench, highlighting the mysteries of deep-sea life.

  • The amphipod, named Dulcibella camanchaca, was found at an extraordinary depth, marking a significant milestone in deep-sea exploration.
  • It is the first predatory amphipod documented in the hadal zone, where depths exceed 6,000 meters.
  • The species showcases unique hunting behavior, differing from typical scavenger amphipods.
  • The genus name Dulcibella is a nod to literary heritage, drawing from Don Quixote, while 'camanchaca' means 'darkness' in local languages.
  • The study is believed to provide insights into extraterrestrial life by offering parallels to ocean moons like Europa and Enceladus.
“The discovery of D. camanchaca enriches our understanding of deep-sea ecosystems and their potential connections to life beyond Earth.”

This groundbreaking discovery emphasizes the need for further exploration of our oceans, which remain largely unexplored, and highlights the unique adaptations of life existing in extreme environments.

title: Artificial Solar Eclipse: Exploring the Sun's Corona - Insights IAS
NASA's Juno mission uncovers heart of Jovian moon's volcanic rage - CGTN
summary:
NASA's Juno mission uncovers heart of Jovian moon's volcanic rage

Publication Date: December 14, 2024 | Source: Xinhua News Agency

Scientists with NASA's Juno mission have revealed new insights into the volcanic activity of Jupiter's moon Io, showing that each volcano is likely powered by individual chambers of magma rather than a single ocean of magma.

  • The finding addresses a 44-year-old mystery regarding Io's volcanic activity.
  • Io, similar in size to Earth's moon, is the most volcanically active body in the solar system, with approximately 400 volcanoes.
  • The Juno spacecraft conducted close flybys of Io in December 2023 and February 2024, achieving proximity of about 1,500 kilometers to its surface.
  • Juno collected high-precision data to analyze Io's gravity and the effects of tidal flexing on the moon.
"Juno's discovery that tidal forces do not always create global magma oceans does more than prompt us to rethink what we know about Io's interior," - Ryan Park, Juno co-investigator.

The insights gained from Juno's mission may also reshape our understanding of other celestial bodies and have broader implications for the study of planetary formation and evolution.

title: 5 latest images universe captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope - HT Tech
Mind-Blowing Discovery, M87 Black Hole's Unprecedented Gamma-Ray Flare Reveals Secrets of Universe's Extreme Environments - Motorcycle Sports Australia
summary:
Mind-Blowing Discovery, M87 Black Hole’s Unprecedented Gamma-Ray Flare Reveals Secrets of Universe’s Extreme Environments

Publication Date: December 2024

Source: Motorcycle Sports

A colossal burst of gamma-rays from the supermassive black hole M87 has captivated astronomers, illuminating the cosmos with intense photons and revealing critical insights into the extreme environments around black holes.

  • The gamma-ray burst lasted three days and emitted photons billions of times more energetic than visible light.
  • The study involved over 300 scientists collaborating on the research to explore the physics around supermassive black holes.
  • The jets created by M87 are 140 times longer than the width of the Milky Way, showcasing immense cosmic forces.
  • Researchers aim to understand the acceleration of particles near the black hole and within the jets.
“We still don’t fully understand how particles are accelerated near the black hole or within the jet,” - Weidong Jin, UCLA.
“These efforts promise to shed light on the disk-jet connection and uncover the origins and mechanisms behind the gamma-ray photon emission.” - Giacomo Principe, University of Trieste.

This groundbreaking observation not only enhances our understanding of black hole dynamics but also invites future explorations into the universe's most profound mysteries. The ongoing investigations hold the potential to significantly advance our grasp of classical physics and the extreme conditions surrounding black holes.

title: SpaceX rolls 7th Starship spacecraft out for testing ahead of next launch (photos) - Space.com
summary:
SpaceX rolls 7th Starship spacecraft out for testing ahead of next launch (photos)

Publication Date: December 11, 2025 | Source: Space.com

The world's most powerful rocket is preparing for its next test flight, with SpaceX's seventh Starship launch expected within the coming month as testing progresses at Starbase, Texas.

  • The Starship upper stage is ready for its own testing following a successful static fire of the Super Heavy booster.
  • SpaceX has not yet announced an official date for the integrated test flight, but NASA has indicated January 11 as a potential target.
  • When fully assembled, the Starship and Super Heavy combination will reach nearly 400 feet tall, surpassing any rocket ever built.
  • Starship aims to be the first fully reusable launch vehicle, with plans for mid-air catches of boosters by the launch tower.
  • There were four Starship launches in 2025, and the number of launches is expected to increase as the program progresses.
"Starship ready for testing ahead of Flight 7," - SpaceX

The upcoming IFT-7 represents a significant step for SpaceX and its partnership with NASA, as Starship is pivotal for future lunar missions under the Artemis program.

title: 5 amazing images of galaxies captured by NASA Hubble Telescope - India.Com
summary:
5 Amazing Images of Galaxies Captured by NASA Hubble Telescope

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: India.com

This article showcases stunning images of various galaxies captured by the NASA Hubble Telescope, highlighting their unique features and beauty.

  • The lenticular galaxy NGC 5283, known for its active galactic nucleus.
  • The jellyfish galaxy JW39, depicted in a serene pose.
  • Galaxy JO204, recognized for its bright gas tendrils.
  • Barred spiral galaxy NGC 685, set against a starry backdrop.
  • The intriguing active galaxy Z 229-15, situated about 390 million light-years from Earth.
"This luminous image from the Hubble Space Telescope shows Z 229-15, a celestial object that lies about 390 million light-years from Earth in the constellation Lyra."

The images displayed provide a glimpse into the vastness of space and the mesmerizing beauty of galaxies, showcasing the incredible capabilities of the Hubble Space Telescope in capturing these celestial wonders.

title: World News Today Live Updates on December 14, 2024 : Geminid meteor shower peaks on December 13-14: Here's how to catch the best view | Today News - Mint
Greenland Glacier Outburst Flood Releases 3,000 Billion Litres of Meltwater - Gadgets 360
summary:
Greenland Glacier Outburst Flood Releases 3,000 Billion Litres of Meltwater

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Gadgets 360

A major glacial lake outburst flood occurred in East Greenland, releasing over 3,000 billion litres of meltwater. This unprecedented event was monitored in real-time for the first time by researchers from the University of Copenhagen.

  • The flood was caused by the release of Catalina Lake into the Scoresby Sound fjord.
  • The water level in Catalina Lake dropped dramatically by 154 metres after a 25-kilometre-long tunnel was carved under the ice.
  • This outburst released water equivalent to three times Denmark's annual consumption.
  • Dr. Aslak Grinsted noted these floods are becoming more frequent due to climate change.
  • The energy released matched that of the largest nuclear power plant for 22 days, highlighting potential renewable energy opportunities.
  • 15 million people globally are estimated to live in areas vulnerable to glacial floods, emphasizing the need for monitoring.
“The outburst floods, driven by climate change, are becoming increasingly common.” - Dr Aslak Grinsted

This significant glacial flood underscores the urgent need for monitoring glacial dynamics as changing climate conditions continue to impact worldwide water levels and energy potential.

title: Hubble Telescope Documents 10 Years of Dramatic Changes on Outer Planets - Gadgets 360
summary:
Hubble’s 10-year journey reveals changes on Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune

Publication Date: December 2023 | Source: NASA

A decade of observations from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has unveiled significant changes in the atmospheres of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, providing valuable insights into the dynamics of these gas giants.

  • Jupiter's Great Red Spot shows changes in size and structure.
  • Saturn's atmospheric conditions vary due to its axial tilt, affecting color and cloud depth.
  • Uranus exhibits increased polar brightness, related to its upcoming summer solstice in 2028.
  • Neptune reveals dark storms and links to the solar cycle, influencing its atmosphere.
“The findings have been shared in over 60 scientific publications, significantly enriching our understanding of planetary atmospheres.”

The results from the OPAL program mark a significant advancement in our understanding of the outer planets, highlighting the importance of continuous observation and research in planetary science.

title: Earth’s Inner Core Might Be Slowing Down and Changing Shape, New Study Reveals - Gadgets 360
James Webb Telescope Confirms the Universe’s Expansion is 8% Faster Than Thought—Here’s Why It’s So Surprising - Indian Defence Review
summary:
James Webb Telescope Confirms the Universe’s Expansion is 8% Faster Than Thought—Here’s Why It’s So Surprising

Publication Date: December 9, 2024

Source: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope

A groundbreaking study from NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope has validated the observation that the universe is expanding at a rate approximately 8% faster than previously predicted, addressing the long-standing "Hubble Tension".

  • The universe is expanding faster than expected, at around 73 km/s/Mpc.
  • Study builds on data from the Hubble Space Telescope and was led by Nobel laureate Adam Riess.
  • The findings highlight the limitations of current models regarding dark matter and dark energy, which comprise 96% of the universe.
  • New research suggests need for refining cosmological models to explain the observed discrepancy in expansion rates.
  • Further data from future observations will help clarify the nature of the universe's accelerated expansion.
“This is the largest sample of Webb Telescope data… and it confirms the puzzling finding from the Hubble Space Telescope that we have been wrestling with for a decade.” - Adam Riess
“Our understanding of the universe contains a lot of ignorance about two elements—dark matter and dark energy— and these make up 96% of the universe.” - Adam Riess

The study not only confirms existing theories but also calls for a reevaluation of our understanding of cosmic forces, suggesting that significant discoveries could be on the horizon as researchers continue their investigations.

title: NASA’s Perseverance Rover Reaches Top of Jezero Crater Rim - WebWire
summary:
NASA’s Perseverance Rover Reaches Top of Jezero Crater Rim

Date: Friday, December 13, 2024

Source: WEBWIRE

The NASA Perseverance rover has successfully reached the summit of Jezero Crater’s rim, marking the beginning of its next science campaign aimed at exploring previously uninvestigated Martian terrains.

  • Perseverance climbed 1,640 feet (500 meters) over 3½ months, navigating steep 20% grades.
  • The rover will commence the “Northern Rim” campaign, potentially visiting four geologically significant sites.
  • The first stop, "Witch Hazel Hill," offers insights into Mars' history with 330 feet of layered outcrop.
  • Future explorations will assess ancient rocks that form the crater rim, dating back 3.9 billion years.
"The Northern Rim campaign brings us completely new scientific riches as Perseverance roves into fundamentally new geology." — Ken Farley, Project Scientist

This mission continues to enhance our understanding of Mars' geology and its early environmental conditions, paving the way for future human exploration.

title: M87's powerful jet unleashes rare gamma-ray outburst - Phys.org
